Enable regex for directory directives (#1452)

* Enable regex for directory directives

The code was already ready for that but escaped the potential regexp declared in
the reek configuration, actually disabling regexp.

This commit fixes this by removing the call to escape.

This allows this kind of declaration in the configuration file:

```yaml
---
[...]
  "engines/.*/test/.*":
    InstanceVariableAssumption:
      enabled: false
    UncommunicativeVariableName:
      enabled: false
```

* Support glob like syntax for directory patterns

This is a mix of currently supported patterns and `glob` patterns.

Currently supported patterns assumes that declared directories includes
sub-directories as well.

`glob` like patterns act like Dir.glob, but are actually backed by a
Regexp, this may lead to some different behaviour.

* Add documentation about Dir.glob pattern for `directory` directives

* Escape . characters

This make sure that the directive does not match an arbitrary character
that is not a `.`.

* Fix code alignment

Clean up calls to Dir.mktmpdir

The use of a first argument with a leading slash is undefined, breaks on
JRuby, and wasn't doing anything useful on MRI either. We can just use
the argument-less version.

Shut Java up about _JAVA_OPTIONS variable

Java and hence JRuby always emits a message about this environment
variable, causing problems in output expectations.

Make no coverage requirements on JRuby

There are two reasons for this:

- Coverage is not collected at all unless JRUBY_OPTS="--debug" is set,
  which slows down tests massively.
- Coverage percentage differs from the result on CRuby, making this
  check unreliable.

what the original filename was, triggering false positives.

original filename, and passes it through to the Examiner and SourceCode
file to use as the `origin` attribute, allowing the configuration
directives to apply.

Emit fingerprints in Code Climate reporter

Emit fingerprints in Code Climate reporter

This enabled Code Climate to more accurately identify whether an issue
is new, as opposed to changed.

I chose to look at the `warning.parameters` value rather than the
`warning.message` value, because the message (for some smell types) will
change over time. For example:

If you have this code:

```ruby
class Alfa
  Bravo = Charlie = Delta = 1
end
```

You will have a warning with message "Alfa has 3 constants".

Later, when you add a 4th constant, it will change to "Alfa has 4
constants".

Ideally, this would be flagged as the same Code Climate issue, but with
a greater remediation points value, so we can flag it as getting worse.
For now, I think it's good to simply treat it as the same issue.

The way this is accomplished is by CodeClimateFingerprint maintaining a
list of parameters to ignore (:count and :depth, currently). I think
this is a good light-weight approach, but am open to the idea of moving
it somewhere else if you're concerend that may fall out-of-sync over
time.

There are two smell types which don't seem to be identifiable based on
smell_type + context + parameters, which are ManualDispatch and
NilCheck. I believe those could become identifiable if they had
parameters, but haven't done that.

Merge pull request #1056 from troessner/refactor-and-simplify-all-our-smell-detector-specs

Refactor and simplify all our smell detector specs.

Refactor and simplify all our smell detector specs.

* Killed all the shared examples
* Introduced our Spec matcher everywhere. This and the bullet point above also have the nice side effect that now all requires at the top of a smell detector spec file look
like this:

```Ruby
require_relative '../../spec_helper'
require_lib 'reek/smells/irresponsible_module'
````

And that's it. No more references to `Examiner`, `CodeContext` and god knows what else.

* Removed silly specs. Some areas of Reek are shockingly under-speced whilst others are over-speced. If we have a threshold of 4 x it is just silly to have a spec that 3 x
does not smell. And 2 x does not smell. And 1 x does not smell. That's just bloated code.

* Removed redundant specs. Bigger smell detector specs were full of duplication.

* Removed foo / bar because I honestly can't see that anymore and replaced it with "alpha/bravo/charlie" as discussed.

* Made our syntax consistent. Introduced heredocs everywhere and removed multi line strings. Introduced newlines. And so on.

* Simplified a lot, a lot of our examples. For instance:

```Ruby
src = 'def simple(arg) args = {}; if arg then args.merge(\'a\' => \'A\') end end'
src = 'def alpha(bravo); if bravo then charlie end; end'
```

The meaning stays the same but the example is less confusing and better readable.

* Introduced the same general examples for every spec at the beginning. Every smell detector spec now starts out like this:

```Ruby
RSpec.describe Reek::Smells::IrresponsibleModule do
  it 'reports the right values' do
    src = <<-EOS
      class Dummy
      end
    EOS

    expect(src).to reek_of(described_class,
                           lines:   [1],
                           context: 'Dummy',
                           message: 'has no descriptive comment',
                           source:  'string')
  end

  it 'does count all occurences' do
    src = <<-EOS
      class Outer
        # Method is necessary because we don't count empty classes.
        def something; end
        class Inner
        end
      end

    EOS

    expect(src).to reek_of(described_class,
                               lines:   [1],
                               context: 'Outer')
    expect(src).to reek_of(described_class,
                           lines:   [4],
                           context: 'Outer::Inner')
  end
end
```

The 2nd spec 'does count all occurences' is only added when it actually makes sense, so there are some detectors that only start with the first spec above.

* Removed contexts that didn't make any sense. E.g. I removed non-nested contexts with only example and just updated the example description. Same goes for specs that were
covered by one giant context.

Merge pull request #356 from troessner/rethinking-configuration

Rethinking configuration.

Rethinking configuration.

There are 3 ways of passing `reek` a configuration file:

1. Using the cli "-c" switch
2. Having a file ending with .reek either in your current working directory or in a parent directory (more on that later)
3. Having a file ending with .reek in your HOME directory

The order in which `reek` tries to find such a configuration file is exactly like above: First `reek` checks if we have given it a configuration file explicitly via CLI. Then it checks the current working directory for a file and if it can't find one, it traverses up the directories until it hits the root directory. And lastly, it checks your HOME directory.

As soon as `reek` detects a configuration file it stops searching immediately, meaning that from `reek`'s point of view there exists one configuration file and one configuration only regardless of how many ".reek" files you might have on your filesystem.

Use parser instead of ruby_parser for parsing

Because parser is currently under more active development and has less
parsing bugs, switch from ruby_parser to parser for parsing the Ruby
code to be investigated.

This has several consequences:
- Flay depends on ruby_parser. To avoid confusion due to ruby_parser
  being available during tests, removes flay as a dependency
- Source code formatting is done with unparser. Unparser tends to
  produce multi-line source for blocks and if statements. These are now
  post-processed to fit one one line, with intermediate lines replaced
  by ellipses.
- Unparser version 0.1.16 does not work on MRI 1.9.2. Support for that
  version of Ruby is therefore dropped.
- Parser uses a different AST with different node types, so all smell
  detectors and sexp extensions have been updated to match.
- Parser uses immutable objects to represent its AST. This means our
  TreeDresses has to create new objects while processing the AST, rather
  than extending the existing ones.
- Parser outputs comments separately from the AST. This means
  TreeDresser now also adds the relevant comments to each node.
- Detection of some smells has improved.
- Reek enforces parsing with parser's 2.1 syntax parser. This is not a
  problem for the kind of use reek has for the AST. Reek also blocks
  parser's warnings about possible syntax differences between Ruby
  patch versions.

Merge pull request #179 from mrclmrvn/master

Fix dup in code example

Allow duplicate calls to variable-like methods

It is common and recommended to create accessor methods and to extract
code into accessor-like methods. The existing implementation of
DuplicateMethodCall would force the result of these calls to be assigned
to a local variable, if it was needed several times in a method. The
resulting code would not be clearer.

The present commit remedies this.

Now, the following code:

  attr_reader :bar

  def foo
    the_bar = bar
    case the_bar
    when :qux
      :baz
    else
      the_bar
    end
  end

can be written as:

  attr_reader :bar

  def foo
    case bar
    when :qux
      :baz
    else
      bar
    end
  end
